lexUnit.name: grunt.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: (of an animal, especially a pig) make a low, short guttural sound.

sentence.text: Zambia grunted uncomfortably and sat down on one of the couches .
His eyes were squeezed tight in agony , and he and the other three men locked in the shafts grunted loudly with exertion as they strove to get the heavy carts rolling again .
I gave it all I had and , grunting loudly enough to raise the dead , I achieved 3 metres 25cm .
At least he only grunted occasionally .
He grunts and groans with the effort .
This animal had begun to grunt and go off her milk two days ago and when I had seen her yesterday I had flirted from one possibility to the other .

And even the most hardened cynic must agree that lying down with your eyes closed listening to music is a lot more appealing than grunting and straining over a set of weights in your local sports centre .
Rincewind grunted as something small and hard struck his ear .
After staring around and grunting a lot , Spunk reflexively saved a drunken girl from being roughed up in a sidewalk fracas outside a singles ' bar .
The bowler approached and grunted with effort as he released the ball .
He grunted with annoyance and sat down in the sparse grass with his back to the worn stone and let the meagre sun warm him .
The hound grunted with pain and he let it fall limp at his feet , a small dark trickle of blood flowing from one nostril .
Swarms of bats appeared over our camp at sunset , and hippos grunted like pigs at intervals throughout the night .
George ignored the sly threat and just grunted .
TWO dozen people are grunting , straining and tearing away at heads and arms -- watched by another member of the Judo Club .
Stefan grunted , rummaged in his folder , and produced yet another sheet of figures .
